body: No, thanks for the heads-up. We generally use `InvariantCulture` for machine-readable data, but in the case of the console sink (where we use a locale-dependent format) `CurrentCulture` seems like the correct default.
Shall I fix and send you a pull request?
No worries, I'll have a look tomorrow
Instead of "current culture" i think we should default to `yyyy MM dd`
@SimonCropp - are you suggesting that it uses invariant by default over current?
I am saying the least ambiguous date format is yyyy mm dd. so that should be the default
@nblumhardt any preference? I can change the PR to use Invariant if that's the general consensus?

Why is `yyyy mm dd` less ambiguous than `dd mm yyyy` or `mm dd yyyy` for that matter, doesn't `yyyy dd mm` exist?

:+1: for `CurrentCulture`, as long as it's just a fire-and-forget thing. Otherwise, I'd go for some ISO8601 representation (which is kinda what @SimonCropp is suggesting).

Thanks for weighing in guys! I've had to think about this one a bit; the original choice of `InvariantCulture` everywhere was an attempt to side-step some of the ugly realities of culture-sensitive formatting, so in this regard I'm actually gravitating back towards @SimonCropp's suggestion, though the format I'd choose would be more like `2014-05-27 22:15:29` - @khellang less ambiguous because `yyyy-` generally appears first in "sortable" formats, where the two-digit month and 24-hr time are needed.

Using a fixed format string only covers the console output scenario, but then, we already accept an explicit `IFormatProvider` to address the issue of formatting data within the log messages themselves.

So perhaps, if it sounds logical to everyone else we change this line:

https://github.com/serilog/serilog/blob/master/src/Serilog.FullNetFx/LoggerConfigurationFullNetFxExtensions.cs#L37

From:

```
const string DefaultConsoleOutputTemplate = "{Timestamp:G} [{Level}] {Message}{NewLine}{Exception}";
```

To:

```
const string DefaultConsoleOutputTemplate = "{Timestamp:yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss} [{Level}] {Message}{NewLine}{Exception}";
```

?

Sounds fine to me, the only issue I had originally was the mm/dd/yyyy vs dd/mm/yyyy as there are 12 days of each month where it's not obvious which format it's in, yyyy-mm-dd fixes that ambiguity.

In that case, do you actually need the changes in my PR or is it just a change to the default format string rather than defaulting an IFormatProvider?
Cool - I think we just need the changes in the format string; thanks for the PR all the same. I'll pop the changes in now.

issue.title: Incorrect date format when using trace sink

repository.name: serilog-sinks-trace
repository.description: The diagnostic trace sink for Serilog.

issue.body:
I know the preamble says to log sink specific stuff in the sink repo, however, I've checked the code for the trace sink and cannot find any sink specific date handling code.

**Does this issue relate to a new *feature* or an existing *bug*?**
- [x] Bug
- [ ] New Feature

**What version of Serilog is affected?  Please list the related NuGet package.**

Serilog 2.9.0
Serilog.Sinks.Trace 2.1.0

**What is the target framework and operating system? See [target frameworks](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/schema/target-frameworks) & [net standard matrix](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/standard/net-standard).**

- [x] .NET Core 3.1
- [ ] netCore 2.0
- [ ] netCore 1.0
- [ ] 4.7
- [ ] 4.6.x
- [ ] 4.5.x

**Please describe the current behaviour?**

The trace sink logs date/time in US format (which is not good, because that's not where I am):-

```
2020-04-02 09:37:54.463 +11:00 [Debug] timestamp: 04/02/2020 00:05:00
2020-04-02 10:27:49.677 +11:00 [Debug] "en-AU"
```

Also, notice the inconsistency... the entry date/time is in some custom format, yet ```DateTime```s in output default to ? (I couldn't find the corresponding standard date/time format string).

```Debug.WriteLine``` gets it right:-

```timestamp: 2/04/2020 12:05:00 AM```

As does the file sink (sort of. better, but not consistent):-

```2020-04-02 09:37:54.463 +11:00 [DBG] timestamp: "2020-04-02T00:05:00.0000000+11:00"```

**Please describe the expected behaviour?**

Use ```CurrentCulture``` instead of assuming I'm in the US.
```2020-04-02 09:37:54.463 +11:00 [Debug] timestamp: 02/04/2020 00:05:00```

Or at least keep the defaults consistent...
```2020-04-02 09:37:54.463 +11:00 [Debug] timestamp: 2020-04-02 00:05:00.000 +11:00```

**If the current behaviour is a bug, please provide the steps to reproduce the issue and if possible a minimal demo of the problem**

```.WriteTo.Trace()```

```
log.Debug("timestamp: {0}", ts);
log.Debug("{0}", System.Globalization.CultureInfo.CurrentCulture);
```


---

I notice this is marked as fixed in https://github.com/serilog/serilog/issues/146 but doesn't seem to apply to the trace sink.

I see at https://github.com/serilog/serilog/wiki/Formatting-Output that I can work around the issue (I think, haven't tried it yet), but shouldn't these all be consistent and use ```CurrentCulture``` by default?

Instead of using ```InvariantCulture``` everywhere, could it keep a ```CultureInfo``` variable somewhere (default to ```InvariantCulture``` if it has to) and let us override in the setup?

It may seem trivial, but can be really annoying when you're working with dates in the first 12 days of the month or adding the same workaround code in every project just for trace.
